title: Babingtons Blends Web Design
metaDescription: Having created the brand identity, packaging and brand assets, we were asked to design their e-commerce site and collaborate on the online strategy to be launched in the UK.

children.text: User research and interface design for Babingtons Blends' e-commerce site and which was the main part of the Italian Tea rooms' launch in the UK market.

I collaborated with our Marketing Director and Social media planner on the online strategy and produced content and campaign material for all of Babingtons' social media platforms and other printed advertising mediums.
Our goal was to recreate a modern and younger version of the Italian tea platform for a target of young tea drinkers in an already very competive tea market.
With the supervision of my creative director I thought out the customer journey by laying out the website architecture, designing the main pages + drawing up the checkout, customer login.
In addition, I worked alongside a Developer, SEO researcher, the Marketing Manager and Social Media Planner.

We knew the brand well, and we agreed something had to change for the UK market and this is where the product rationalisation came in. The stucture of the website had to be simple, but also the formats of products needed to be immediately recognisable. We explored various bold and colourful styles for both site and products.

title: Mannequin Packaging Redesign
subtitle: Packaging Redesign and Sustainability Analysis

children.text: This project aimed to blend Italian craftsmanship with sustainability, focusing on redesigning packaging for Bonaveri. We reviewed processes, materials, and costs, incorporating prototyping, environmental analysis, and user experience improvements. Collaborative efforts ensured the eco-friendly, practical packaging aligned with Bonaveri's standards, highlighting a comprehensive, stakeholder-engaged approach to innovation and design.

team: Selene Bonato - Claudia Gelmini - Bianca Draghetti
skills: Prototyping and Testing / Environmental Impact Analysis / User Experience Design / Stakeholder Engagement

children.text: The solution was a modular and collapsible design that minimized environmental impact without compromising on elegance. This innovative packaging was easier to transport and store, reducing the carbon footprint associated with the distribution of Bonaveri's products and enhancing the unboxing experience for clients.

title: Sustainable Solution for Mannequin Packaging
metaDescription: Reducing quantity and swapping materials for eco-friendly solutions helped us maintain the high standard of protection the mannequins need to arrive intact at their destination.

children.text: Reducing the quantity of materials and swapping them for eco-friendly solutions helped maintain the high standard of protection the mannequins need to arrive intact at their destination.

title: Babingtons Blends' UK Strategy
metaDescription: Graphics, animations and campaign material for Babingtons Blends

children.text: Fun and witty artwork created for printed and digital campaigns across Babingtons Blends' online platforms, OOH and printed mediums.
We created a responsive website design for Bervini’s online shop and I was also responsible for creating the content needed for their online launch.

Working closely with Marcello Minale on various projects for Babingtons Blends, the famous Victorian Tea Rooms in Rome, was exciting. Being Anglo-Italian, I felt complete synergy when creating graphics, illustrations, and animations for their marketing campaigns to launch their new platform in the UK. This project marked a slightly different journey from previous ones, targeting a new market outside Italy.

Our aim was to create material that was quirky and colourful, young and witty, rejuvenating the historical brand's image for the UK market. Over two years, I contributed to website UX/UI design, printed adverts for magazines, OOH, B2B/B2C stationery, and online content.

Moving away from the British-Italian essence that characterised our previous designs for Rome, we introduced wit for consumer interaction with the product and brand. We played with the word 'Tea', integrating it with Victorian illustrations across the branding assets and using a bold, condensed typeface for loud and indiscreet presence on all platforms. Naming products and bundles playfully, we maintained Babingtons' essence while adapting the new brand, Babingtons Blends, for better positioning in the UK market.

Constrained by small budgets for photo-shoots, we relied heavily on graphics, typography, and illustrations to build the online brand image. Launching a new brand in the UK's competitive market demanded a distinct approach, leading to the creation of "We don't just sell tea".

Working closely with the directors, especially the Marketing Director and the Social Media Manager, offered a comprehensive insight into brand launching, from the e-commerce platform to the final social media content and timeline.

The goal was to create a website that reflected Bervini's values, bringing the simplicity of Italian vineyards to online consumers. The design used visuals, illustrations, and narratives inspired by their vineyards, encouraging users to explore a less impactful way of drinking. "Bere bene" meaning "Drink well" guided our approach.
I was in charge of UX research, UI design, and prototyping in Adobe XD, along with creating online content and graphics.

We needed to maintain packaging costs below current low levels, especially considering the mannequins' most fragile parts—the arms and hands—which are pre-attached. Another challenge was improving the ergonomics for workers filling the packaging, previously an uncomfortable task due to the use of polystyrene chips. This required a complete redesign of the packaging to enhance sustainability, practicality, and adherence to Bonaveri's luxury image.

By creating a bespoke box specifically for the arms, and rethinking the box's internal layout, we streamlined the process, reducing costs and waste. This new eco-friendly packaging is easier to handle and aligns with Bonaveri's values, offering an organized presentation and improved aesthetics.

The new sustainable and eco-friendly packaging we designed at Bonaveri was adopted by the company and received recognition. It was awarded a prize by Conai for its outstanding concept, excelling both technically and in design.

We needed to maintain packaging costs below current low levels, especially considering the mannequins' most fragile parts—the arms and hands—which are pre-attached. Another challenge was improving the ergonomics for workers filling the packaging, previously an uncomfortable task due to the use of polystyrene chips. This required a complete redesign of the packaging to enhance sustainability, practicality, and adherence to Bonaveri's luxury image.

By creating a bespoke box specifically for the arms, and rethinking the box's internal layout, we streamlined the process, reducing costs and waste. This new eco-friendly packaging is easier to handle and aligns with Bonaveri's values, offering an organized presentation and improved aesthetics.

The challenge was to evolve from a youthful image to embody Luisa's more mature market position. My task involved designing unique patterns for each wine, crafting motifs that narrated Luisa's story, and completing the artwork to showcase the brand's sophisticated legacy.
As a mature, family-run business and a returning client of Minale Tattersfield, Luisa sought a label refresh in 2019 to mirror its established reputation in both local and international markets.

The challenge was to evolve from a youthful image to embody Luisa's more mature market position. My task involved designing unique patterns for each wine, crafting motifs that narrated Luisa's story, and completing the artwork to showcase the brand's sophisticated legacy.
